content.title: Marfan Syndrome - Vascular Manifestations
content.summary: Autosomal dominant connective tissue disorder caused by FBN1 gene mutations affecting fibrillin-1, leading to aortic root aneurysm, dissection, and other cardiovascular complications.

definitions.definition: Autosomal dominant connective tissue disorder caused by mutations in FBN1 gene encoding fibrillin-1, with multisystem involvement including cardiovascular, ocular, and musculoskeletal systems.
Diagnostic criteria for Marfan syndrome (revised 2010) emphasizing aortic root dilation/dissection and ectopia lentis as cardinal features, with systemic features score.

key_concepts.explanation: Primary vascular features include: aortic root dilation (sinuses of Valsalva), aortic regurgitation, mitral valve prolapse, and type A aortic dissection. The ascending aorta and root are most affected; descending aortic disease occurs later.

Z-score normalizes aortic root diameter for body surface area. Z-score ≥2 is significant; ≥3 is severe. In adults, aortic root >40mm indicates increased risk; surgery typically recommended at 50mm (45mm with risk factors).

Prophylactic surgery recommended at: 50mm (no risk factors), 45mm (family history of dissection, rapid growth >5mm/year, severe aortic regurgitation, pregnancy desire), or 40mm if undergoing other cardiac surgery.
David operation (reimplantation) and Yacoub procedure (remodeling) preserve the native aortic valve while replacing the aortic root, avoiding need for lifelong anticoagulation.

evidence.finding: Aortic root dilation (Z-score ≥2) or dissection + ectopia lentis sufficient for diagnosis; FBN1 testing supportive but not required

evidence.citation: Lacro et al., Pediatric Heart Network Atenolol vs Losartan Trial, 2014
evidence.finding: Both beta-blockers and ARBs reduce aortic root dilation rate; no significant difference between agents

clinical_pearls: Annual echocardiography is standard surveillance; upgrade to CT/MRI when root approaches surgical threshold
Beta-blocker therapy should be started at diagnosis to reduce aortic wall stress
Pregnancy carries significant risk of aortic dissection; aortic root >40mm is relative contraindication
After root surgery, surveillance of remaining aorta is mandatory - chronic dissection and aneurysm can occur
FBN1 testing useful for family screening but not required for clinical diagnosis
learning_objectives: Apply the revised Ghent criteria for Marfan syndrome diagnosis
Interpret aortic root Z-scores in Marfan syndrome
State surgical thresholds for prophylactic aortic root replacement
Compare valve-sparing versus Bentall root replacement procedures
Describe lifelong surveillance requirements after aortic surgery
